resources.string: Are you sure you want to delete this?
Are you sure you want to completely erase the database? This can not be undone!
Data parsed, please confirm the input
The exported file is on your SD card in the file:
The data in the following file has been imported:
There was an error while saving the service interval!
This service for %s is due. Would you like to delete this service reminder?
A quick description of the service
Press Menu to add a new Service Interval
No description set! This is a required field!
Start mileage was never set, or is invalid.
No interval duration has been specified, or is invalid.
Interval duration has not been set, or is invalid.
Invalid number format for price of fuel.
Invalid number format for amount of fuel.
Invalid number format for odometer reading.
Select an item to import or export that file format
When importing SQLite databases it is extremely important to know that it will overwrite your current database. All local changes will be lost forever.

Importing comma-separated value (CSV) files is useful for providing spreadsheet integration. Note that the format is pretty specific; if you are not sure of the format, it's highly recommended that you export a CSV, open it in Excel, insert your values, and then import the resulting spreadsheet.
Importing SQL is highly dependent on the database schema. If you do not know what you're doing with this, it is recommended you use another option.
Exporting the SQLite database will create a direct copy of your current SQLite database and place the resulting copy on your SD card.
Exporting a comma-separated value (CSV) file will export your current database into a .csv file on your SD card. This file can then be used in Excel or any other spreadsheet editor.

Exporting your database as SQL will create a .sql file on your SD card. These SQL commands can then be imported into any other database engine of choice, provided that the schemas match. Note that the table-creation SQL is omitted; it is up to the end user to create the necessary tables.
From this screen, you can add a new vehicle, or select an existing vehicle to edit. Note that you can long-press on a vehicle in the list to bring up a context menu to perform some common operations.

From here, you can change attributes about an existing vehicle. If you decide to not save your changes, simply press the back button to undo the changes. Note that there must always be at least one vehicle, so you can not delete the last vehicle. If you have multiple vehicles, you can choose to set this vehicle as default, so that it is always first in the list.

This allows you to add new vehicles to your database. This may be helpful if you drive two vehicles, or multiple vehicles share a database. You can optionally set this vehicle to be the default vehicle.

You can add incremental fill-ups (since the previous one) by prefixing your odometer with a '+'. For example, if you have gone 300 miles since your last fillup, enter '+300'. In portait mode, an on-screen keyboard will appear for making quick edits. Note that this keyboard is numeric only.

The history browser lets you view a list of past fill-ups, of all vehicles. Once a fill-up is selected, you can edit or delete individual entries. If the economy is in red, then it is below your average economy value. Green indicates a value above your average economy value. Blue means that it is the same as your average fuel economy.

From here, you can edit a previously-recorded fill-up, or delete it altogether. Press the back button to undo any changes you have made and return to the history browser. You can fill in an optional comment, if you want to.

From this screen, you can set preferences to fit your usage. The Orientation setting determines when the UI should rotate. A setting of 'device' means that it will rotate when you rotate the device, whereas 'keyboard' will rotate when you open the keyboard tray.

This screen shows a wide range of calculated statistics on a per-vehicle basis. If you have multiple vehicles, a drop-down will show, and you can switch between vehicles. Note that statistics can not be calculated on vehicles that do not have enough data stored, so you'll get a warning about that.

The charting buttons display graphs of various statistics, usually over time. The divider between the sections marks the average value. The red section shows which values are below average and the green, above average.

Here you can add a new Service Interval, or edit an existing one by selecting it from the list. You can also delete one directly by long-pressing on the item in the list and choosing the "delete" option.

This screen allows you to create a new Service Interval. For your convenience, there are several preset intervals with generic distances and durations. When creating your Service Interval, you specify the mileage when you last had this service done, and the date which it was done. You then enter how long it should be before the next one, and how far you have to go. You will then be reminded when you either pass the date or the mileage; whichever comes first.
Here you can edit an exisiting Service Interval, as well as delete the Interval by pressing Menu and choosing the "Delete" option.
